misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves an acceleration calculation problem instead of the assigned sum of even numbers problem. The code reads 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration, which is entirely different from the required task of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the acceleration calculator problem, not the sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from user input, checking which ones are even (using the modulo operator n % 2 == 0), accumulating their sum, and printing the result. For example: input '3 8 2 7 4' should output 'Sum of even numbers: 14'

Calculates acceleration formula (v1-v0)/t instead of summing even numbers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
No accumulator pattern
misconceptions.root_cause: Either the student submitted the wrong file, copied code from a different assignment, or fundamentally misunderstood the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to sum EVEN NUMBERS from 5 integers. Start fresh: (1) Create a loop to read 5 integers, (2) Use if(n % 2 == 0) to check if even, (3) Add even numbers to a running sum, (4) Print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with no overlap to the assigned task (sum of even numbers). This is a clear case of task mismatch.
